sn47.18:4.1: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying near Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
sn47.18:4.2: Then as he was in private solitude this thought came to his mind:
sn47.18:4.3: “The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to complete the procedure, and to realize extinguishment.
sn47.18:5.2: A mendicant would meditate by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.18:5.3: Or they’d meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.18:5.5: or principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.18:5.6: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to complete the procedure, and to realize extinguishment.”
sn47.18:6.1: Then Brahmā Sahampati knew what the Buddha was thinking.
sn47.18:6.2: As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm,
sn47.18:6.3: he vanished from the Brahmā realm and reappeared in front of the Buddha.
sn47.18:6.4: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his cupped palms toward the Buddha, and said:
sn47.18:6.5: ‘That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!
sn47.18:6.6: Sir, the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to complete the procedure, and to realize extinguishment.
